definitions.definition: to fall down or fall in suddenly, often after breaking apart

examples.text: The roof collapsed under the weight of snow.
The building had partially collapsed.
Several buildings have collapsed into the ocean.
Timber buildings may simply rot and collapse.

definitions.definition: to fall down (and usually become unconscious), especially because you are very ill

examples.text: She collapsed and was rushed to hospital.
The man collapsed in a heap on the floor.
He collapsed in the street and died two hours later.
One night I practically collapsed from exhaustion.
He collapsed with shock.
She collapsed suddenly from a heart attack.
The man collapsed against the wall and slid down it.
They finally arrived, collapsing from fatigue.

definitions.definition: to sit or lie down and relax, especially after working hard

examples.text: When I get home I like to collapse on the sofa and listen to music.
Talks between management and unions have collapsed.
All opposition to the plan has collapsed.
The home side collapsed spectacularly in the second half.
The coalition collapsed under the pressure of differences between the two parties.
His building firm collapsed and he went bankrupt.
The scheme collapsed in the face of determined opposition.
The region's economy has virtually collapsed.
In November the strike finally collapsed.

phrases: to collapse in the face of something

definitions.definition: to decrease suddenly in amount or value

examples.text: Share prices collapsed after news of poor trading figures.
She lost a lot of money when the property market collapsed.

definitions.definition: to fold something into a shape that uses less space; to be able to be folded in this way

examples.text: The table collapses for easy storage.

definitions.definition: if a lung or blood vessel collapses or is collapsed, it falls in and becomes flat and empty

wordOrigin: early 17th cent. (as collapsed): from medical Latin collapsus, past participle of collabi, from col- ‘together’ + labi ‘to slip’.
